Sawaddee ka welcome to the second episode of my 
five colors of Thai rice series in the previous

episodes we took a look at our trusty white 
jasmine rice and today we're going to look at

the healthier cousin brown jasmine rice now I 
know there are a lot of people out there that

say I don't like brown rice it doesn't taste 
good it's tough it tastes like twigs I used to

be one of those people okay but I'm going to 
guess that if you don't like brown rice it's

because you haven't had Thai jasmine brown rice 
so this is the exact same rice variety as the

white jasmine rice so you still get a fluffy 
texture and a nice aroma except you also get

the nutritional benefits of the bran and the germ 
that's left on the rice now the brand is the brown

jacket I like to call it but you see on the rice 
and the germ is the Pioneer white dot on top of

each grain of rice and those are where almost 
all of the Rice's vitamins minerals fiber are

located so you get rid of the brown stuff you 
get rid of pretty much most of its nutritional

benefit and just like we talked about in the 
previous episode you can look for the little

green yellow logo right here to make sure you are 
getting genuine jasmine rice grown in Thailand

and to cook brown jasmine rice it's exactly the 
same as cooking white rice except you might need

a little more water and a little more time but 
you don't really need to rinse off the starch

like you do white rice because all the stars 
is sort of trapped in the little brown jackets

however I like to give it one rinse anyway because 
sometimes you see a stray hole or two floating to

the top and then I just pour that off and for 
water I use for one cup of brown rice one and

a half cups of water now that might sound less 
than what you would use for other kinds of brown

rice but this is jasmine rice it's super tender it 
really doesn't need that much water and remember

you can always add more water through the rice pot 
and then just keep it cooking longer if you need

to but if you add too much water game over and 
also if you want to make sure all the nutrition

is kept in the right don't use the pasta method 
like we talked about in the previous episode

so brown rice has a slight - which I love and 
it's also got a nutty aroma but it's so mild

and neutral that I find it still goes well with 
anything that you're making if you've got picky

little eaters though what you can do is mix 
brown and white rice together and I promise

you no one will complain that's how I started 
eating brown rice when I was little now some

people tell me that they want to eat brown rice 
100% brown rice but none of their family members

are quite sold on it yet so I have a tip for 
you you can make a whole bunch of brown rice

for yourself pack them in individual portions 
and freeze them then comes dinner time you can

make white rice for your family and just pull out 
your portion microwave for 90 seconds and it'll

be as good as new and you can also make fried 
rice with brown rice and it'll be even easier

because the brand sir prevents the rice from 
clumping together so you won't have that problem

one very important thing to note is that you 
notice brown rice has an expiration date and that

is because brown rice unlike white rice does go 
bad and it goes fast quicker than you might think

that's because the oil that's in the bran and the 
germ that'll go Rams it over time and you can tell

because when you open the bag and smell it it is 
smell like rancid oil not good and you shouldn't

eat it because rancid oil is actually not good 
for your health so I would recommend storing

your brown rice regardless of whether it's open or 
not in the fridge or in a cool dark place and that

concludes the second episode of my five colors of 
Thai rice series I got so many really interesting

ones coming up so make sure you subscribe if 
you haven't done so so you won't miss those and

if you've got more questions about rice get in 
touch with me on Facebook Twitter or Instagram

and all through my website at ifixit.com
